unnormalised: **Rental Agreements: Your Paisa Vasool Guide to Peace of Mind (Before You Move In!)**
normalised: **Rental Agreements: Your Paisa Vasool Guide to Peace of Mind (Before You Move In!)**

unnormalised: Hey everyone, Raj here! So, you've found your dream PG in Bandra or that perfect 1BHK near your office in Gurgaon. Awesome! But before you start planning your housewarming party (and inviting Sharmaji and all your college buddies), let's talk about something super important: the rental agreement.
normalised: Hey everyone, Raj here! So, you've found your dream P G in Bandra or that perfect one B H K near your office in Gurgaon. Awesome! But before you start planning your housewarming party (and inviting Sharmaji and all your college buddies), let's talk about something super important: the rental agreement.

unnormalised: Think of the rental agreement as the "mangalsutra" of your landlord-tenant relationship. It's what binds you both (legally, of course!). It might seem like a boring formality, but trust me, a well-drafted agreement can save you a whole lot of headache and heartache later. No one wants a "Kyunki Saas Bhi Kabhi Bahu Thi" drama with their landlord over something silly.
normalised: Think of the rental agreement as the "mangalsutra" of your landlord-tenant relationship. It's what binds you both (legally, of course!). It might seem like a boring formality, but trust me, a well-drafted agreement can save you a whole lot of headache and heartache later. No one wants a "Kyunki Saas Bhi Kabhi Bahu Thi" drama with their landlord over something silly.

unnormalised: What should you be looking for? Well, obviously the rent amount (duh!), but also things like the security deposit (kitna dena hai? Rs. 20,000? Rs. 50,000?), the lock-in period (if any), and the notice period for vacating (usually 1 month, right?).
normalised: What should you be looking for? Well, obviously the rent amount (duh!), but also things like the security deposit (kitna dena hai? Rupees twenty thousand? Rupees fifty thousand?), the lock-in period (if any), and the notice period for vacating (usually one month, right?).

unnormalised: Make sure the agreement clearly states who's responsible for what – who pays the electricity bill? Who's responsible for fixing that leaky tap in the bathroom? (You or the landlord?). What about those pesky maintenance charges? Get everything in writing!
normalised: Make sure the agreement clearly states who's responsible for what – who pays the electricity bill? Who's responsible for fixing that leaky tap in the bathroom? (You or the landlord?). What about those pesky maintenance charges? Get everything in writing!

unnormalised: And don't just blindly sign whatever your landlord puts in front of you. Read it carefully! Maybe run it by a lawyer friend if you're unsure. Pay special attention to the clauses regarding renovations or alterations. Can you put up that awesome poster of Shah Rukh Khan? Or paint the walls your favorite shade of Sabyasachi green? Better to know beforehand!

Better to know beforehand!

unnormalised: Also, important! Check the agreement start and end dates – something like 01/01/2024 to 31/12/2024 is standard, but double-check! You don’t want any surprises at 09:00 hrs on 15/08/1947 (okay, maybe not that date, but you get the idea!).
normalised: Also, important! Check the agreement start and end dates – something like first january two thousand and twenty four to thirty first december two thousand and twenty four is standard, but double-check! You don’t want any surprises at zero nine zero zero hours on fifteenth august nineteen forty seven (okay, maybe not that date, but you get the idea!).

unnormalised: Getting your rental agreement registered is also a good idea, especially for longer tenancies. It makes it legally more solid and can be useful if there are any disputes down the line. You can usually do this online these days; check the registration charges at your local sub-registrar’s office.

unnormalised: Finally, keep a copy of your signed agreement safe and sound! You might need it later – even if it's just to prove that your rent is only Rs. 15,000, not Rs. 20,000 like your landlord suddenly claims at 17:00 hrs on 26/01/2024!
